In this section, we present our system model and problem formulation.
We consider a system with a set of parties

.
The parties communicate via a central server, forming
a hub-and-spoke architecture.
The parties and the server may have different operating speeds,
and these rates may change over time.
We will formalize party operating speeds in Section

references:
We first study the effect of training with heterogeneous optimizers.
We run Flex-VFL and train on the MOSEI dataset with parties either using
standard SGD or SGD with local momentum.
We consider a case where all parties and the server have the
same operating rate.
We let the computation time for each party be 111 time unit
and set the timeout for each global round to be 202020 time units.
Thus, each party runs 202020 local iterations in each global round.
We let the communication latency be 101010 time units.
We measure the average time taken to achieve a target mean-square error (MAE)
over 555 runs.
The results are given in Table II.
The best optimizer combination over the five runs is using
standard SGD at the video and audio parties that train LSTMs, while
the text party uses SGD with local momentum to train the BERT model.
Thus we can see a benefit from choosing different optimizers at each
party depending on the local model architecture.
We use this combination of optimizers for the rest of the experiments with the MOSEI dataset.

references:
In Table III we show the time units it takes to reach a target test accuracy.
For the MOSEI dataset, we let the target be 0.650.650.65 Mean Absolute Error (MAE),
a common measure of performance for the dataset.
We can see that for the MOSEI dataset, P-BCD and VAFL
perform best when communication latency is low.
However, as communication latency increases, Flex-VFL is able to
reach the target MAE twice as fast as Sync-Min-VFL and P-BCD,
and four times as fast as VAFL.
For the ImageNet100 dataset, the target is set to 60%percent6060\% top-555 accuracy.
In this case, P-BCD performs well when communication latency is low.
As the communication latency increases however, Flex-VFL overtakes P-BCD,
benefiting from local iterations saving on overall communication.
Finally, for the ModelNet40 dataset, the target is set to 70%percent7070\%.
Here, Flex-VFL always performs better than the other algorithms,
regardless of communication latency.
In our experiments with ModelNet40, there are a larger number of
parties than in the other datasets.
This causes the heterogeneity of party operating speeds to
have a greater effect on time-to-target accuracy.
With the chosen distribution of party operating speeds, Flex-VFL
reaches a target accuracy up to four times as fast than other VFL algorithms.
In the next subsection, we consider how different operating speed
distributions can affect performance of each VFL algorithm.

references:
Table IV shows the time taken for Sync-VFL and Flex-VFL to
achieve 70%percent7070\% top-555 accuracy on the ModelNet40 dataset for different timeouts.
We see that for Flex-VFL, increasing the timeout improves the time-to-target, up until
a timeout of 404040 time units.
We see this same trend with Sync-VFL when changing the number of local iterations.
This is in line with previous works that explore
the effect of local iterations on convergence rate [7, 58, 3].
Increasing the number of local iterations improves time-to-target up to a
certain point, where the error incurred by local iterations outweighs the benefits to
convergence rate.
We can also see in Table IV that Flex-VFL outperforms Sync-VFL
regardless of the timeout.
